item.title: Police Release Man Misidentified as Brussels Airport Attacker
item.description: The police, appealing to the public for help, said the real assailant remained at large.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS and KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers patrolling in Brussels on Sunday.

item.title: Vietnam’s Battle With Tuberculosis
item.description: A country’s stunning progress against tuberculosis may be threatened by reduced support for a health care system stretched thin.
item.category: Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria
United States Agency for International Development
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.media:credit: Justin Mott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nguyen Quang Thieu, 53, waiting to have his lung X-Ray scan examined by Dr. Hoang Thi Phuong, head of the Respiratory Tuberculosis Department at the National Lung Hospital in Hanoi.

item.title: Saudis Announce Prisoner Swap With Houthis in Yemen Conflict
item.description: It was only the second publicly announced prisoner swap since the Saudis’ intervention a year ago, and by far the biggest, ahead of a planned April 10 cease-fire.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Houthi rebels at a tribal gathering showing support for the Houthi movement in Sana, Yemen, last year. Saudi Arabia released 109 Yemenis in return for nine Saudis in a prisoner swap with the Houthi rebels announced Monday.

item.title: Raghavendran Ganesan, Software Engineer From India, Dies in Brussels Attack
item.description: Mr. Ganesan’s family appealed to Indian officials and others via social media in a frantic search for their lost relative.
item.dc:creator: KATIE ROGERS
item.media:description: Raghavendran Ganesan, in a photograph taken from social media.

item.title: Lauriane Visart, 27, Belgian Lawyer, Dies in Brussels Attacks
item.description: Many Belgians got to know Ms. Visart, who was killed in a suicide attack at the Maelbeek subway station, after her father gave a moving interview.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN
item.media:description: Lauriane Visart in a photograph taken from social media.

item.title: Bangladesh Editor Faces 79 Court Cases After an Unusual Confession
item.description: After admitting it was wrong to have years ago published allegations against the prime minister, Mahfuz Anam could be sentenced to 175 years in prison.
item.dc:creator: MAHER SATTAR
item.media:description: Mahfuz Anam, center, the editor of The Daily Star, Bangladesh’s most popular English-language newspaper, outside a court in Rangpur District this month.

item.title: In 2 Minutes, Bangladesh Rejects 28-Year-Old Challenge to Islam’s Role
item.description: The High Court dismissed a petition, filed in 1988, that aimed to remove the designation of Islam as the state religion and struck a nerve among Bangladeshis.
item.dc:creator: MAHER SATTAR and ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: Leaders of an Islamic group gave gestures of victory in Dhaka, Bangladesh, on Monday after the country’s top court dismissed a petition that aimed to remove the designation of Islam as the state religion.

item.title: Victims of the Brussels Attacks
item.description: Thirty-five victims from at least eight countries were killed in the attacks. Here are profiles of some of the victims, updated as more names are confirmed.

item.title: Cairo Journal: Sprawling Mural Pays Homage to Cairo’s Garbage Collectors
item.description: The artist eL Seed used more than 50 buildings as his canvas to celebrate the Egyptian capital’s trash collectors, who are largely viewed as second-class citizens.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:credit: David Degner for The New York Times
item.media:description: The French-Tunisian artist eL Seed assembled a team to paint a large mural across many buildings in the neighborhood that is home to Cairo’s garbage collectors.

item.title: Comments by Donald Trump Draw Fears of an Arms Race in Asia
item.description: The Republican front-runner said he would consider withdrawing U.S. forces from Japan and South Korea if they did not spend more on military defense.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: American troops participating in joint military exercises with South Korea this month in Pocheon, near the border with North Korea.

item.title: Mélanie Defize, Brussels Victim, Was a Music Lover With a ‘Candid Smile’
item.description: Ms. Defize, 29, a producer at an independent label in the city, was a baroque violinist who contributed articles to an opera-focused publication.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE
item.media:description: Mélanie Defize was among those killed in the attack on Maelbeek subway station on March 22.

item.title: Chinese Writer in Germany Says 3 Siblings Are Detained Over Xi Letter
item.description: Chang Ping denies any connection to the mysterious letter, which denounced the Chinese leader and called for his resignation.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China. Chinese security officials have detained 11 people so far in a widening investigation of the origins of an online letter denouncing the iron-fisted rule of Mr. Xi.

item.title: Pakistan in Mourning as Toll From Lahore Suicide Bombing Rises
item.description: Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif arrived in the city in a show of solidarity, after a faction of the Pakistani Taliban claimed responsibility for the attack.
item.dc:creator: DANIYAL HASSAN and SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:description: Family members mourned on Monday in Lahore, Pakistan, after a suicide bombing in a park a day earlier killed dozens.

item.title: Israel Changes Tack After Standoff With Brazil Over Dani Dayan
item.description: Plans to name the former settler leader as envoy to the South American nation were dropped after Brasília refused to approve the appointment.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: The former settler leader Dani Dayan, who has been appointed consul general in New York, at a conference in Jerusalem on Monday on fighting a boycott against Israeli goods.

item.title: Sinosphere: Q. and A.: Duncan Clark on ‘Alibaba: The House Jack Ma Built’
item.description: Mr. Clark’s new book explores how Mr. Ma built the Chinese e-commerce platform that is now one of the world’s most valuable companies.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: Jack Ma, founder and executive chairman of the Alibaba Group, during a panel discussion held this month as part of the China Development Forum in Beijing.

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Trump's New World Disorder
item.description: Trump thinks America is being ripped off and NATO is obsolete, but war in Estonia or the East China Sea could be the biggest rip-off of all.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Malaysia’s Immigrant Worker Debate
item.description: The country’s powerful economy has drawn in millions of foreigners, at the cost of sharp social tensions.
item.dc:creator: TASH AW

item.title: French Journalist Is Detained at U.N. War Crimes Tribunal
item.description: Florence Hartmann, a former correspondent for Le Monde, has been locked up at the tribunal prison to serve a pending seven-day sentence for contempt of court.
item.category: International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: MARLISE SIMONS
item.media:description: Florence Hartmann was arrested on Thursday, before the genocide verdict against Radovan Karadzic, the former Bosnian Serb leader, was given.

item.title: Al Jazeera Announces Layoffs, Mostly in Qatar
item.description: An estimated 500 positions will be cut as part of a reorganization that the global news organization attributed to shifts in the media landscape.
item.dc:creator: ELI ROSENBERG

item.title: Shaxi Journal: An Ancient Caravan Town in China Is Reborn
item.description: In a project praised by Unesco, a Swiss-led team spent years renovating the square of Sideng Village, with an eye toward historical consistency that is rare in China.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sideng Square in the old town center of Shaxi, Yunnan, China, in January.
